moves.1. e4: Team Match, I am playing white. Open Game.
moves.1... c6 2. d4: Black wants the Caro-Kann, so I follow with the main line.
moves.2... d5 3. Nd2: One of the two options to follow the Classical Variation, the other being 3. Nc3.
moves.3... dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3: With 4. ... Nd7 black enters the Smyslov/Karpov Variation
moves.5... Ngf6 6. Ng3: No real reason I avoided exchanging knights other than to keep the black bishop off of f4, a place it seems to like to go in the Caro-Kann.
moves.6... e6 7. Bc4: Weak. The white bishop here has nothing to do and is easy to drive off if black so wishes.
moves.7... Be7 8. O-O O-O 9. Qe2: A bit of a plan starts to form.
moves.9... b6 10. Re1: Black's 9. ... b6 seems fairly passive, and gives white time to build pressure in the center. If black doesn't respond carefully, he's about to lose material, at least the e6 pawn and more if black is careless.
moves.10... Bb7 11. Bxe6: Black misses it. so white pounces. Black pays the price for passive moves in the opening.
moves.11... fxe6 12. Qxe6+: Black recaptured and now the white queen forks the black king and the bishop on d7. There is only one move that handles the check and saves the bishop, but black dare not play it...
moves.12... Rf7 13. Ng5: But he did. Now black is in lots of trouble. 13. ... Qf8, 14. Nxf7 Qxf7, 15. Qxe7 leaves white winning by rook and pawn. Black chose to resign.

gameName: The Price of Passive Moves in the Opening
